I'm having trouble with what seems to me to be basic subtheming; I'm wondering if I've forgotten the basics!

I want to create a bunch of subthemes of a contrib theme that only differs by a single CSS file. When I create it, I can see in Chrome Dev Tools that the CSS file is being picked up, but it's being overridden by the parent theme's CSS file. Isn't that the opposite of what's supposed to happen?

When I copy the contrib theme and place the subthemes inside it, it works as expected.

Am I missing something? I know subthemes can be inside the parent theme's folder, but they don't have to be, do they?

The relevant bit in my .info file looks like this:

base theme = contrib_theme_machine_name
stylesheets[all][] = mynewstyle.css
No, they don't need to be in the base theme's directory.
Does a new stylesheet work? Is it only when overriding a base theme stylesheet that you have a problem?
I haven't explicitly tried it, but a new style should work. The style is there, it's just being overridden by the original style.

Here's my .info file:
image.png
And here's the body tag in dev tools: image.png
OK, so the styles are being overridden, not the stylesheet itself...
Oh, I think I just figured it out -- the min version is overriding the regular one.
Are the base theme's stylesheets being loaded after the sub theme's in the HTML head somehow?
That seems unlikely. I'm not doing anything fancy, I'm only adding the css in the theme's info file
I'm going to try doing the name thing with minimized files
I think I just figured out my mistake.
Ah, I think it's because the Bootstrap CSS file is coming from a CDN...
That's not my current theory :)
I changed the filename of the CSS file in the subtheme.
I figured the styles would take precedence over the same styles, but now I realize that's naive.
I should leave the filename alone, that way Backdrop will squeeze the original out of the array, so it doesn't have to override it -- the original will be gone. (I think...)

If you want to completely remove a base theme stylesheet, then yes, you need to use the same name. But I just tested this with a simple sub-theme of bootstrap_lite and even a custom CSS file's CSS is being overridden...
Does that feel like a bug to you?
I suspect it's specific to Bootstrap Lite...

Yeah, look at this:

<style media="all">
@import url("http://sandbox.lndo.site/themes/bootstrap_lite/css/style.css?qlb9rk");
@import url("http://sandbox.lndo.site/themes/test/test.css?qlb9rk");
</style>
<link rel="stylesheet" href="//netdna.bootstrapcdn.com/bootstrap/3.3.5/css/bootstrap.min.css" media="all" />
<link rel="stylesheet" href="https://maxcdn.bootstrapcdn.com/font-awesome/4.4.0/css/font-awesome.min.css" media="all" />
<style media="all">
@import url("http://sandbox.lndo.site/themes/bootstrap_lite/css/overrides.css?qlb9rk");
</style>

Bootstrap's CDN-based CSS is being loaded after my 'test' theme's CSS (and thereby overriding it).
sunnoafbitch :scream:
I specifically want to override bootstrap.css

I think you'll need to open an issue for Bootstrap Lite, asking to change the way they add their CDN CSS. They do it in hook_css_alter() and even though they set a negative weight, it doesn't seem to have any affect on where the CSS is loaded. I suspect they should instead be calling backdrop_add_css() in a different function...

backdrop-contrib/bootstrap_lite
Bootstrap Lite - a Backdrop Bootstrap-based theme: - backdrop-contrib/bootstrap_lite

It actually says this in "admin/appearance/settings/bootstrap_lite"

"Use BootstrapCDN to serve the Bootstrap framework files. Enabling this setting will prevent this theme from attempting to load any Bootstrap framework files locally."
So if I disable the CDN (which there's an option to do) it should work the way I was expecting it to.
And that does

Yes, it's only the CDN thing that's causing the issue. And it seems there's an existing issue in the queue for this: https://github.com/backdrop-contrib/bootstrap_lite/issues/13

That sounds like something I should be able to confidently say I can do; let me give it a shot.

After reading that thread, I'm less confident. I didn't see a patch the solved the issue. When you say "file a PR" does that imply fixing the problem first? It's possible I could do that -- the code looks like stuff I understand -- but I'd have to dive into it with more commitment.

In the meantime, I think I can solve my practical problem by adding a template.php file to each subtheme with this bit in it:

<?php
/**
 * Implements hook_css_alter().
 */
function NAMEOFYOURSUBTHEME_css_alter(&$css) {
  // Add overrides.
  $theme_path = backdrop_get_path('theme', 'NAMEOFYOURSUBTHEME');
  $override = $theme_path . '/css/suboverride.css';
  $css[$override] = array(
    'data' => $override,
    'type' => 'file',
    'every_page' => TRUE,
    'media' => 'all',
    'preprocess' => TRUE,
    'group' => CSS_THEME,
    'browsers' => array('IE' => TRUE, '!IE' => TRUE),
    'weight' => 1,
  );
}

Btw, the driving force behind what I'm doing is to make BootSwatch themes easily available. At some point it would be nice to fix the code in Bootstrap_lite that allows a user to select a bootswatch theme, but for usability reasons I want to implement my workaround anyway.

Yes @Luke McCormick ...a PR that fixes the issue means that you've fixed it on your local fist :sweat_smile: ...I mean a "proper" way that fixes the original issue you are having here (making sure that the CDN-based CSS file is loaded before any subtheme CSS, so that the subtheme CSS takes priority)
Ok, in that case it's something I could probably do "if given enough time" but unlikely to do given the time I have. I thought the problem was already solved and just needed to be packaged up.
Alternatively, you can solicit the help of others, or see it there's anyone willing to become a maintainer of that theme. That way, they will fix things for everyone using it.

In the meantime: I think I need a little help implementing the phptemplate solution above. Besides substituting in the subtheme names, I think (but I'm not sure) that I need to specific the specific CSS files that should use the local version?

Specifically, this line:

$override = $theme_path . '/css/suboverride.css';

Does that only affect files named "suboverride.css" ? So I should replace "suboverride.css" with the name of the file I want to override? Or is this doing something more general, and suboverride.css is a name of something somewhere else within Backdrop?
I'm conducting a GovCMS training this week, so I need to focus on that. Then I would like to focus on the 1.18.0 core release as much as possible, so I cannot help with contrib as much ATM. Sorry.

At the end of the Smashing Magazine article is a paragraph that references a number of interesting-sounding tools, most of which seem to now be gone. That's not surprising, since they were presumably written for earlier version of Bootstrap, and they probably all used LESS and not SASS. I wonder if there are similar tools available that work with current versions?

Several third-party generators are also available on the Web. Unlike the official generator, they provide live previews as you adjust variables. Bootswatchr organizes itself by variable, and StyleBootstrap by component. BootTheme adds a roll-the-dice feature to randomize your values. If lady luck isn’t on your side, Lavish can generate a theme from any image you provide, and PaintStrap from existing color schemes.
